 1. BASIC EDUCATION IN CHINA A. BACKGROUND AND CURRENT STATUS Sector Reform Agenda 1.1 Educational development is a major instrument in China's drive for modernization to the end of this century and the early stage of the 21st century. Educational reforms and development, responsive to the changing human capital demands of the growing economy, were encapsulated in a series of policy and legal documents, such as "Decision to Reform the Educational Structure" (1985), "Compulsory Education Law" (1986), "Outline for Reform and Development of Education" (1993), and "Education Law" (1995). The current reforms relevant to basic education focus on the following areas: (a) the provision of nine years' basic education for all school-age children; (b) the development of vocational and technical education at the secondary and postsecondary levels; (c) the strengthening of education management at all levels by strengthening the role of principals and local authorities in the design of the reforms, and transferring the responsibility for providing basic education to local governments under the central government's policy guidance and financial support; (d) the great increase of investment in basic education by the governments at all levels; (e) the continuous improvement and gradual standardization of school operational conditions; (f) the enhancement of teachers quality by further strengthening of teachers' education and training. The State Education Commission (SEdC), created in June 1986 as the successor to the Ministry of Education (MOE) and responsible nationally for policy, budgeting and coordination of this sector, therefore has the mission of overseeing the above reforms at the national level. Basic Education: Targets and Current Situation 1.2 China's achievements in the provision of comprehensive schooling have been spearheaded by pursuing the national target of achieving universal basic education (UBE) with differential timescales throughout the country. In 1986, the Government passed a "Compulsory Education Law" that instituted a nine-year basic education system, divided into two stages: primary education (with 5 or 6 grades) and lower secondary (with 3 or 4 grades, depending on provincial plans). According to specific implementation plans, "compulsory" education should be achieved gradually in different regions, with urban and more developed areas in the interior achieving universal education first, and less developed areas more gradually. Universalization of the nine-year program throughout China is expected to be achieved by 2000. 1.3 National criteria for successful achievement of nine-year compulsory education are highly specific and include the following: net enrollment rates for primary education
 -2 - of over 98 percent and the transition rate into lower secondary of approximately 95 percent; retention rates of over 97 percent within each year at the primary level; promotion of more than 95 percent of primary completers to lower secondary; and a national completion rate of 98 percent for primary education in urban and developed areas, with individual provinces determining completion rates for lower secondary. Dropout rates at primary level are to be held at under 1 percent and under 2 percent at lower secondary level. The ratio of qualified teachers at primary level will be more than 90 percent and at lower secondary more than 80 percent. The illiteracy rate among the population aged 15 is not to exceed 1 percent. Floor space norms for primary schools are 3 to 5 square meters per pupil and 4 to 6 meters for lower secondary. Refinements of these norms change according to number of classes in the school, with the unit generally decreasing as the number of classes increases. 1.4 Criteria for poor rural areas are different. The net enrollment target rate for primary schooling is 95 percent; for lower secondary is 85 percent; and dropout rates for primary and lower secondary are 1 percent and 3 percent, respectively. The percentage of primary graduates among the 15-year-old population is determined by the provinces. The illiteracy rate among the 15-year-old population is not to exceed 5 percent. The enrollment and dropout rates for girls, and illiteracy rate among girls aged 15 will follow provincial criteria. More than 90 percent of rural primary teachers (the same as the national criterion) and not less that 70 percent of lower secondary teachers will be qualified. 1.5 Despite the challenges posed by an 80 percent rural population, and immense variations in agricultural and economic conditions, China has already gone far in meeting these targets. In 1994, enrollment rates for the first nine years of schooling were reportedly 98.4 percent of the 6-11 age cohort enrolled in primary education, and more than 60 percent of the 12-15 age cohort in lower secondary schools. Of primary graduates, 81.8 percent went on to secondary schools (regular or vocational). Almost 98 percent of all school-age girls were enrolled in primary education. A significant consequence of these high enrollment figures is the high literacy rates: 80 percent for those above 15 years of age and about 93 percent among those between 15 and 25 years of age. The projected figures for 2000 are 134 million pupils at primary level, compared to 124 million in 1994, and 70 million at lower secondary level, an appreciable increase over the 41 million students in 1994. Currently, China runs the largest primary school system in the world, with 5.6 million teachers and about 697,000 schools. At the lower secondary level (typically grade 7-9), there are 2.6 million teachers and 68,500 schools. Regular senior secondary schools number 14,000, with 560,000 teachers. 1.6 China's record of progress may be attributed to five factors: a strong and sustained political commitment to the development of basic education as evidenced by the growth in public expenditures on education from Y 9.9 billion in 1983 to Y 41.4 billion in 1993 (constant 1987 Renminbi) (see Annex 1, Table 1.3); effective organization at all levels from the national to the local; the overall national policy of decentralization to local authority and responsibility; strong community support to and participation in

THE BASIC EDUCATIONAL SYSTEM: DISPARITIES AND ISSUES 1.7 Global figures, though indicative of substantial progress, tend to mask disparities in basic education development. Because the bulk of funding for primary and lower secondary schooling falls on the shoulders of local governments at the village, township and county levels, there are noticeable imbalances in the availability of educational services between the economically advanced regions that can amply supplement national funds, and the underdeveloped areas with very limited resources. For example, the average rural income in poor counties is Y 400 compared with the national rural average of Y 921.6.' Generally, urban and coastal areas have achieved the goal of nine-year basic education but many poor, sparsely-populated and remote areas have not reached primary education targets. The State Council in its recent "National 8-7 Poverty Reduction Plan (1994-2000)" designated 592 counties to be national poverty counties which, as a consequence, will be the focus of special poverty-targeted programs, financing and other interventions. These counties are variously called "national poverty counties" or "8/7 counties." Schooling in these national poverty counties is marked by poor attendance and high repetition and dropout rates. 1.8 The net enrollment ratio (NER) for primary school-age children now lags the national average of 97.7 percent by a significant margin in five provinces-Sichuan, Guizhou, Gansu, Yunnan and Qinghai-and in three autonomous regions-Tibet, Ningxia and Xinjiang. The proposed project covers counties in Qinghai while the other four provinces plus Xinjiang and Ningxia have been covered by earlier basic education projects. Regional disparities are also indicated by completion rates (proportion of children entering first grade who eventually complete grade 5). While the national average in 1991-92 was estimated at 91 percent, it ranged between 99.7 percent in Beijing and 78.6 percent in Jiangxi Province. 1.9 Two groups in the poor areas tend to be particularly disadvantaged-minority nationalities and girls. This reflects both cultural factors and the poverty of the inhabitants, who need children to help the family subsist. In areas populated by minority nationalities, economic and education levels are lower than the national average. China has 55 minority nationalities totaling 91.2 million people and constituting 8 percent of the population. Areas inhabited by these minorities cover 64 percent of the entire country. There are 80 spoken languages and over 30 writing systems used by the minority nationalities. In a study of school age children in 25 minority counties conducted by the State Education Commission, the gross enrollment rate was 20 percentage points lower than the national mean, with female enrollment being particularly low. This occurs despite findings of a household survey done in four poor counties in two provinces, l Both are State Statistical Bureau (SSB) figures for 1993 expressed in 1993 prices.

(See para. 5.7 for more details.) 1.10 Among the deprived sections of the population, girls and women continue to be more disadvantaged. Facilities for basic education are equally available for boys and girls, yet there is a significantly lower level of utilization of facilities by girls. Almost half the rural population is illiterate or semiliterate, and women make up 70 percent of this number. While almost 98 percent of all school-aged girls nationwide were reportedly enrolled in primary education in 1994, an increase of nearly 80 percent over that of China in 1949, about two thirds of 2.6 million school-age children not in school in 1994 were girls. China's western regions and remote, rural areas show even worse enrollment levels. Government studies have identified economic, sociocultural, and religious hindrances, and lack of information regarding the potential benefits of education as the major factors constraining girls' education. 1.11 The disparity in basic education coverage between coastal/urban areas and poor, rural areas is manifested in a range of specific problems, the most notable being: (a) Rural primary and lower secondary schools are more inefficient than their urban counterparts. This is evidenced by low student-teacher ratios, incomplete schools, low completion rates, and low girls' enrollments, particularly in minority schools. A survey of 328 counties in 1992 found an inverse correlation between net income per capita and dropout and repetition rates; the lower the net income, the higher the dropout and repetition rates. Some estimates show that nearly one third of the children who enter grade I in poor areas drop out before completing grade 5. Generally, there are no mechanisms to identify efficiency-related issues and to provide and monitor corrective measures. (b) Seriously underfinanced rural schools in poor counties provide highly inadequate schooling facilities. Buildings are in such poor physical condition that they are officially classified as "dangerous." In counties in the proposed project area, 6 percent of primary schools and 5 percent of lower secondary schools have dangerous buildings. The school environment is not conducive to learning: bilingual instruction facilities, which are needed to teach non-Chinese speaking minority children, are lacking; both books and instructional equipment are scarce. The average figure for project county schools meeting equipment standards for primary level is 28 percent, increasing to 45 percent for lower secondary schools. Distribution of teachers is uneven between urban and rural areas; the low
 pay of minban2 teachers in poor communities results in low motivation and a high turnover. (c) Primary schools in poor and minority areas often do not offer all six grades. About 30 percent of the rural primary schools in project counties are incomplete schools, i.e., they do not offer the full primnary program and some offer only three or even fewer grades. Small villages are served by "teaching points" which offer only two grades, 1 and 3 or 2 and 4: counties in the proposed project currently have 9,726 (1993) such "teaching points." Since complete primary schools may be located 4 to 5 kilometers away from small villages and boarding schools are costly, many children tend to discontinue their education after attending an incomplete school. (d) Gender disparity persists. Low enrollment of girls is most evident in Gansu, Guangxi, Guizhou, Ningxia, Sichuan, Tibet, Qinghai and Yunnan, where a significant proportion of the population belong to national minorities. The primary school completion rates for boys and girls in these eight provinces in 1991-92 were 94.2 percent and 89.3 percent, respectively, with girls constituting about 75 percent of dropouts from the primary cycle. While the literacy rate for the male population of 15 years and older in provinces was 87 percent in 1990, it was only 68 percent for females. Negative sociocultural attitudes among some communities toward education of girls, the relatively poor recognition of the benefits of education for girls, school fees which constitute a substantial proportion of meager incomes, need to assist families with income-generating activities, and parental hesitation to send girls to coeducational schools without female teachers provide some of the reasons for lower enrollment and retention rates for girls, especially those belonging to disadvantaged population groups. The perceived lack of relevance of the school program to the future development and occupational needs of girls also has important bearing on attitudes to their schooling. (e) Inadequately planned and managed teacher training programs, both at preservice and inservice levels, especially in poor rural areas with relatively high levels of minority population, continue to hinder progress towards universalization. Nationally, 83 percent of primary school teachers meet State-prescribed qualifications: regional disparities range from 94 percent in Liaoning to 49 percent in Tibet. The average figure for project counties is about 70 percent for primary school teachers and 47 percent for lower secondary. Courses in multigrade teaching and bilingual instruction are not widespread. About 37 percent of primary school teachers are minban teachers, 88 percent of whom are in rural areas. While significant efforts have been made to develop a training network to periodically reorient teachers to curriculum and methodological innovations, opportunities for inservice training for experienced teachers in poor, remote and minority areas continue to be inadequate. Low ratios of students to teachers (STR) bear testimony to the need to increase the efficiency of teacher deployment and management: in project counties the average STR for primary schools is 20.8:1 and for lower secondary schools it is 15.5:1. (f) Inadequate management capacity for planning, implementing, monitoring and evaluating reform programs for universalization of basic education poses difficulties in poor counties. Several tiers of government and administration are involved (central, provincial, county, village and educational institution) which make management tasks complex: appropriate structures are lacking to facilitate the systematic involvement and assistance of the community in the planning and implementation of primary education programs. At a number of management levels, there are shortages of qualified and experienced planners, data-processors, statisticians and analysts. Educational statistics and data on education financing, on school facilities, and on staff deployment are often incomplete or inaccurate and therefore provide insufficient information to identify and resolve efficiency problems such as wasteful student to staff ratios, low teaching loads, and low utilization rates of facilities and equipment. C. GOVERNMENT STRATEGY, POLICIES AND PROGRAMS 1.12 The Central Government's overall approach toward education is to develop broad principles and regulations to guide provincial and local governments in their county and village level education services, so that they may implement the compulsory education law using the resources available, and pursue their own targets, according to their own means. Principles to be encouraged at the national level include efficiency, quality and equity: * efficiency is seen as increased cost-effectiveness in school management by reducing high repetition and dropout rates, and adopting adequate student- teacher ratios and teacher workloads; and by implementing better-managed and better-conceived teacher training programs;
 -7 - * quality improvement includes the introduction of newly developed sets of more relevant and effective books for basic education, training of teachers to use the new text materials and provision of more preservice and improved inservice training for teachers; and * equity issues include State efforts to subsidize economically undeveloped areas so that they may introduce compulsory education and to encourage the transfer of funds from provincial to local county governments. 1.13 Government's Education Strategy for Poverty Areas. According to the Education Law," the most important basic law in education and effective from September 1, 1995, it is the Government's legal responsibility to support and assist the development of education for national minorities as well as remote and poverty stricken areas (Article 10). In keeping with the "Outline for Reform and Development of Education in China," the State Council issued detailed suggestions in 1994 on the implementation and planning for universalization of basic education, especially in poor areas, which has been undertaken on the basis of different timescales, according to the status of economic development as indicated in the following four categories: (a) Category 1: cities and selected rural areas with a fairly high level of economic development and covering 40 percent of the nation's population. Universalization targets in these areas are expected to be achieved by 1997. (b) Category 2: rural areas with medium level of economic development and covering another 40 percent of the population. This category has already achieved universal compulsory primary education and expects to meet nine-year targets by 2000. (c) Category 3: rural areas with low levels of economic development covering 15 percent of the country's population. For about 5 percent of this group, in areas with a good primary education system, the nine-year goal should be achieved by 2000. For the remaining 10 percent of this group, efforts will be made to implement five or six years of basic education. (d) Category 4: exceptionally poverty-stricken areas covering 5 percent of the population. 1.14 In order to reach overall universalization, targets proposed by the State Council, through SEdC, will increase nonrecurrent categorical budgetary expenditures in all provinces with nationally designated poor counties so that they can achieve universal basic education by the year 2000. This is called the "Basic Education Program in Poor Areas" and funding will be used for school construction, provision of teaching equipment and library books, and teacher and principal training. (See para 1.15 for details.) The annual special funds allocated by the Central Government for the program will be
 - 8 - increased to Y 1.0 billion in three years. As Beijing, Tianjin, Shanghai, Guangdong, Jiangsu, Zhejiang, Jilin, Liaoning and Shandong have almost achieved the goal of universalization of nine-year compulsory education, SEdC decided to implement the program with a two-phase strategy: • Phase One (1995-98) focuses on Category 2 poor counties in the 12 provinces of Anhui, Fujian, Hainan, Hebei, Heilongjiang, Henan, Hubei, Hunan, Jiangxi, Shaanxi, Shanxi and Sichuan. These provinces account for approximately 40 percent of China's population. There are 289 "8/7 Counties" in Phase One with a population of some 110 million. The emphasis in Phase One is on lower secondary schooling. * Phase Two (1995 through 1998 to 2000 and beyond) will focus on Category 3 counties in the nine provinces and autonomous regions of Gansu, Guangxi, Guizhou, Inner Mongolia, Ningxia, Qinghai, Tibet, Xinjiang and Yunnan, accounting for some 190 million population. There are 273 "8/7 Counties" in Phase Two with a poor population of some 70 million. By 2000, 66 percent of Category 3 population would have been covered, which will mean that almost 91 percent of the nation will have nine-year compulsory education coverage. The government's strategy for Category 4 population areas is to include it in Phase Two and to universalize three to four-year primary education by 2000. 1.15 Total funding required to reach these goals by the year 2000 is estimated at Y 15.0 billion. The government efforts include: (a) earmarked national funds for construction and rehabilitation of schools in poor areas; (b) upgrading the professional qualifications of minban teachers so that they can be converted to gongban (government supported) teachers; (c) specially targeted funds to support payment of charges for books, meals in boarding schools, and some transportation costs; (d) training of education managers at the provincial and county level in methods to achieve efficiency gains by using better resource allocation strategies and practices; and, (e) introduction of tax reforms that broaden and deepen the base for tax collection, earmark percentages for compulsory education, and allow for targeting of funds toward the poorer sections of the provinces. 1.16 The "regular part" of the special fund amounted to Y 200 million in 1995. China's strategy for the provision of education for ethnic minorities has undergone changes in the past four decades. For instance, use of minority language as the initial medium of instruction in primary schools has increased and Han language lessons are introduced later as a part of bilingual teaching. Han Chinese is only fully used in later primary school grades as the medium of instruction. The percentage of local content in primary school textbooks has been increased, and levels of government-both local and national-support of teachers' salaries in predominantly minority areas have been increased. Also, there has been since the 1 970s an increased recruitment of minority teachers and school principals, and greater efforts to train bilingual teachers. 1.18 Government policy on minority education can be seen in a number of other systematic policy foci: E Expanding Access through: construction, expansion and renovation of township/village schools, teaching points and multigrade schools; mandating universal six-year education in all minority regions or an elementary graduate per household as a minimum requirement for remote and scattered rural inhabitation; development of a Center4 Elementary School for every township in each minority county and a Center Secondary School and a Literacy and Vocational Training Center for each minority county; * Improving Delivery and Relevance of educational inputs by: improving teacher selection and preparation in pedagogy, bilingual education, curriculum revision and development of bilingual materials for minorities; and * Increasing the Resource Base by developing preferential policies of increased national and provincial resource allocation targeted at basic 4 "Central" schools are generally town or county center level schools with additional faculty and funding provided by the province or county to provide inservice teacher and principal training, local curricula development and instructional equipment training sites.
 - 10- education in poor minority regions for specific programs to reduce repetition and dropout rates. 1.19 Government Strategy for Promoting Education of Girls. In the "Law of the People's Republic of China on the Protection of Rights and Interests of Women," which became effective on April 3, 1992, the Government's policy position regarding the education of girls is evident, seeing it as a societal responsibility: * Schools and departments concerned shall, by implementing the relevant regulations of the state, guarantee that women enjoy equal rights with men in such aspects as starting school, entering a higher school, job assignment upon graduation, conferment of academic degrees and dispatch for study abroad (Article 15). * The governments, society and schools shall, in the light of the actual difficulties of female school-age children or adolescents in schooling, take effective measures to ensure that female school-age children or adolescents receive compulsory education for the number of years locally prescribed (Article 17). 1.20 In the "Education Law," the policy is: "all citizens, regardless of ethnic group, race, sex, age, occupation, property status or religious belief, enjoy equal educational opportunities according to law" (Article 9). 1.21 Several other measures have been taken to create a supportive environment for the promotion of girls' education. Legal protection for the rights and interests of women and girls is enshrined in the Compulsory Education Law and The Law Regarding the Health Care of Mother and Infants. The State Council issued the "Outline for Women Development in China" right before the UN Fourth Conference on Women in Beijing, and further highlighted the importance of girls' education to women's development and social status. Publicity drives have been initiated and the Chinese Government has expressed its determination to keep girls' dropout rate and lack of attendance to under 2 percent. Several initiatives are being piloted in efforts to identify the best strategies: among these are the Gansu Province project to improve primary education for girls and disadvantaged groups; and a joint activity on the "Current Status, Issues and Strategies of Girls' Education in the Rural Areas" conducted by research institutes in Ningxia, Gansu, Guizhou and Qinghai Provinces. Teacher training is being strengthened, especially for female teachers and principals. Social action in the form of financial assistance through the "Hope Project" and the "Spring Bud Plan" illustrate national efforts to help retain girls in school by lowering direct costs of schooling to parents. 1.22 In addition, a UNICEF-assisted project "Promoting Education of Girls in Poor Areas," started in 1992, is being implemented in selected townships in 101 counties in nine provinces (Anhui, Gansu, Guangxi, Guizhou, Ningxia, Qinghai, Shaanxi, Sichuan and Yunnan). Specific strategies adopted under the project include, amnong others,
 campaigns to generate parental awareness of the benefits of girls' education and to overcome the socioeconomic barriers hindering participation of girls in education, mobilization of parents and community leaders in activities designed to enhance enrollment and retention of girls in schools, further increasing the proportion of trained female teachers and principals and incorporation into the school curriculum learning content that would enable girls to acquire the knowledge and skills relevant to their socioeconomic needs; specific measures implemented in minority areas of Ningxia include establishment of single-sex schools and single-sex classes and promoting participation of religious leaders in enrollment campaigns and school improvement activities. Activities under the proposed project would help in enhancing enrollment and retention of girls in the areas covered. D. BANK GROUP INVOLVEMENT IN THE SECTOR 1.23 Sector Strategy. The Bank Group is in general agreement with the direction taken by China in development of its educational system at all levels. It provides support to this process by maintaining a dialogue on sectoral issues and options, and by supporting selected activities which contribute to the efficiency and quality of that system and to its relevance to national development objectives. In order to facilitate achievement of these ends, IDA's sectoral focus is to: * support basic education with a strong focus on increasing access to quality schooling for the poor, minorities and girls; * improve the effectiveness of teaching services including the upgrading of the teacher training curricula; * assist in the design and implementation of reforms in the education sector, in line with the "Guidelines for Development and Reform of China's Education System," especially in seeking more equitable funding mechanisms, targeted to basic education in poor rural areas; and * support institution building to increase the capacity of educational authorities at all levels to carry out their responsibilities, especially under conditions of increasing operational decentralization. It is within the above context that the effort to improve and develop basic education, both through the ongoing Educational Development in Poor Provinces (EDPP) Project (Cr. 2339-CHA) and Basic Education in Poor and Minority Areas (BEII) (Cr. 2651-CHA) Project and the currently proposed project takes place. 1.24 Past Bank Group Involvement in the Sector. In line with the above assistance strategy, since 1981 the Bank Group has supported 16 projects in China that were either devoted entirely to the education sector or had substantial education sector components. Total recurrent cost in 2001 is the sum of the total regular recurrent costs of personnel and nonpersonnel inputs in 2001 and the total annual recurrent cost implication of the project. The total annual recurrent costs implication of the project is equal to the sum of the annual costs needed to maintain the effectiveness of project investments in school buildings, equipment, furniture, and technical assistance. In this analysis, the annual costs of maintenance of an education input is estimated to be the product of a coefficient for that input and the project investment in that input. The coefficient will vary across education inputs and across project counties. It is between 2 and 3 percent for school buildings, between 3 and 4 percent for equipment, between 1 and 2 percent for furniture, and between 0.1 and 0.3 percent for technical assistance. BENEFITS 5.1 The project is expected to benefit about 8.3 million of the poorest school children in some of the more economically disadvantaged counties of some of China's poorer provinces. It will significantly expand basic education among the poor, especially in the remote areas inhabited by minority nationalities. Provision of education to remote and rural areas not only helps to create opportunities for rural development but also provides the skills necessary to participate in economic growth in township and urban centers. Minority nationality students will be better prepared to participate in Chinese schools in the upper and post-secondary levels. Other aspects of the project specifically focus on delivery of educational inputs for poor girls with fee remission and free textbooks provided under the student assistance subcomponent, as well as targeted training of female principals and gender sensitive teacher training programs. Furthermore, the project includes specific interventions designed to improve planning and management capacity of the central, provincial and county governments to prepare and implement similar comprehensive projects and to replicate them in other parts of the country. The project will have a direct impact on between a third and all (depending on the county) of the schools and children in 124 counties (covering approximately 46,000 schools) and will provide varying lengths of training for approximately 138,000 teachers and education managers. Five areas of economic and financial analysis pertaining to the project have been undertaken: (a) an analysis of the financial feasibility of development targets for compulsory education in the project counties during 1996-2000; (b) an analysis of the financial feasibility of development targets for compulsory education in project provinces during 1996-2000; (c) an analysis of the sustainability of the project in the project counties after its completion in 2001; (d) an assessment of the availability of counterpart funding; and (e) an examination of the financing and operative guidelines of a student-assistance program (see Annex12).

This finding was reinforced by the analysis on counterpart funding. However, the burden of counterpart funding still remained relatively high for counties in the other three provinces; and the ratio of counterpart funding to IDA investment was over 1:1 for two of these provinces. 5.6 Based on the findings of the analyses of feasibility, sustainability, and counterpart funding, provinces decided not to reduce their contribution to the counterpart funding which will mean that the ratio of provincially provided counterpart funds will rise in relationship to the county proportion, thus taking some of the financial pressure off the counties. Results of a household survey on household education spending (HES) conducted as part of project preparation indicate that in the four national poverty counties covered by the study, HES averages were between 9 to 11 percent of total spending of a household and between 14 to 31 percent of the net income of a household. (An alternative estimate indicates that the proportion can be as high as 83 percent.) HES is a heavy economic burden for a significant proportion of households in the four counties, especially when economic burden is measured as a ratio of HES to household income. A sizable number of households have to borrow money or receive subsidies from relatives and friends in order to support the household costs of schooling. 5.8 Through piloting the student assistance program in the project counties, provincial authorities will develop financing and operating guidelines for this program. There are three main risks in this project. First, the provinces may not ensure that the population in other poor counties (not covered in the project) would benefit from improved access to and quality of basic education. To deal with this, the project provinces will be required to implement acceptable action plans with monitorable indicators to ensure that education achievements in nonproject poor counties will not deteriorate during the implementation. Second, the central, provincial and county officials may be unable to oversee the implementation of the project activities. Cognizant of this risk, management strengthening at all three levels is a principal activity of the project. Additionally, lessons learned from implementing the IDA-supported EDPP and Basic Education II projects will be included in the training of provincial and county level implementation units for this project. Finally, there may be inadequate commitment on the part of SEdC, project provinces and counties, which may result in insufficient counterpart funding to match IDA credits. However, SEdC has indicated that it is willing to allocate sufficient amounts of its own annual budgetary allocation for poor counties to the seven project provinces to assure adequate counterpart funding (see Annex 19 and 2Q).  - 75 - ANNEX 12 ANNEX 12: ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 1. As part of the preparation of the Third Basic Education Projection, economic analyses in three broad areas have been conducted: (a) education and poverty reduction; (b) financial analysis; and (c) quality and internal efficiency improvement. The findings are summarized briefly in the following. Details are given in the background documents prepared for such analyses and can be found in the project file for economic analysis. A. EDUCATION AND POVERTY REDUCTION 2. This area is concerned with the issue of whether the project will contribute to poverty reduction and benefit its intended population groups. Four types of analyses have been conducted: the relationship between education and income in rural China; strategies for targeting project resources; mobilization of additional education funds for poor counties; and financial assistance to poor students. Review of Studies on Education and Income in Rural China 3. There is a large English literature on the relationship between education and income. Studies in many countries (not including China) have found that individuals with higher levels of education have higher income and that the rates of return to education are generally positive and substantial (Psacharopoulos, 1994; Lockheed, Jamison & Lau, 1980). In order to find out the education-income relationship in China, the mission has asked the Institute of Higher Education at Peking University to conduct a review of such studies in the Chinese literature since the 1980s. The review finds that there are very few studies of education and income in China. However, there are three studies that estimate the private rate of return to education. The private rates are all positive though they are somewhat lower than the average private rates for other countries in the English literature. For example, a study based on 1992 data on rural households in Guizhou province found that the private rate was 9.7 percent for primary education and 7.8 percent for lower-secondary education. Nevertheless, these rates were higher than those reported in another study of rural households in China in 1986 (Jamison, 1987). The apparent increase in the private rate over time is consistent with Schultz's hypothesis that the effectiveness of education is enhanced in a modernizing environment (Schultz, 1976). But there are too few studies from which to draw any definitive conclusion about the pattern of private rates of return to education in rural areas in China over time. Further research is needed to determine the magnitude of the education-income relationship and its pattern over time in the changing environment in China.

To enhance the efficiency of education investment in this project, four types of strategies have been employed in project design for targeting project resources toward its intended population groups. The first type is geographical targeting by which only nationally-designated poor counties in the project provinces are included in the project (the so called 8-7 counties). The second type is ethnic targeting, which seeks to increase the involvement of minority populations in project activities. The third type is gender targeting, which promotes girls education in the project counties. A number of indicators related to minority and girls education have been identified and will be used in project monitoring. The project also incorporates a number of measures to promote girls and minority education, including a student assistance program which gives particular attention to girls and minority students. The fourth type of targeting seeks to place more project investment in primary education than in lower-secondary education and to focus more on incomplete primary schools (schools with grades I to 3 or 4) than on complete primary schools (schools with grades I to 6). Throughout project preparation and appraisal, the project investment costs in the project proposals presented by the seven provinces were examined to encourage these four types of targeting. Data were collected by the socioeconomic survey teams of the State Statistics Bureau located in the concerned counties. One hundred households in each county were selected based on the sampling method used by the State Statistics Bureau in its annual survey of rural households in China. 9. The survey found that households in these poor counties spent a significant amount of their resources on the schooling of their children. The economic burden of education spending was heavy for some households and these households had to borrow money or receive subsidies from relatives and friends in order to send their children to school. Financial Sustainability 18. The financial sustainability of the project is assessed by comparing the projected total recurrent cost of compulsory education in project counties in 2001 with the projected recurrent budget for compulsory education in project counties in 2001. Total recurrent cost in 2001 is the sum of the total regular recurrent costs of personnel and nonpersonnel inputs in 2001 and the total annual recurrent cost implication of the project. TIhe total annual recurrent cost implication of the project is equal to the sum of the annual costs needed to maintain the effectiveness of project investments in school buildings, equipment, furniture, and technical assistance. In this analysis, the annual cost of maintenance of an education input is estimated to be the product of a coefficient for that input and the project investment in that input. The coefficient will vary across education inputs and across project counties. It is between 2 and 3 percent for school buildings, between 3 and 4 percent for equipment, between I and 2 percent for furniture, and between 0.1 and 0.3 percent for technical assistance. The projected recurrent budget in 2001 was estimated on the basis of the actual recurrent expenditure in 1994 and a historical growth rate. 19. The analysis shows that the project was clearly not sustainable in two of the seven provinces. The development targets and project size for the counties in these two provinces were reduced. Though the project appears to be sustainable for the counties in a third province, the recurrent budget in 2001 was based on a somewhat optimistic growth rate; the development targets and project size were also reduced for this province. The project was found to be sustainable for the counties in the other four provinces. doc.abstracts: The main objectives of the Third Basic Education Project are to: 1) support the attainment of universal primary education and the expansion of coverage of lower secondary education in poor and minority areas; and 2) build stronger institutions responsible for education delivery. The project will support the government's efforts to make primary education universal by the year 2000 by putting more educational inputs into teaching points, increasing the enrollment in complete schools, expanding multigrade and multisubject teaching in rural areas, and reducing dropouts rates of minority children through improved bilingual educational programs. The project consists of the following components: 1) an institutional component comprising: (a) facilities upgrading; (b) instructional equipment, furniture and books; and (c) staff upgrading; 2) a management improvement component including: (a) local education management training; (b) project management training; and (c) expansion of education management information system; and 3) a central component consisting of: (a) national training; (b) research dissemination program; (c) stipend program; (d) study tours; (e) experts panel; and (f) studies.
